Remainder Theorem

When the polynomial \(P(x)\) is divided by \(x-a\), the remainder is \(P(a)\), i.e. in the notation above, \(r=P(a)\).

Proof

We have established that we can write \(P(x) = (x-a)Q(x) +  r\) for some \(Q(x)\) and \(r\).

Using this, \[ \begin{eqnarray} P(a) &=& (a-a)Q(a)+r \\ &=& 0\times Q(a)+r   \\ &=& r, \end{eqnarray} \] which is what we wanted to show.


For the example above, \(P(x)=x^2+x-10\), we worked out that the remainder when dividing by \(x+4\) is \(2\), and indeed \(P(-4)=16-4-10=2\).
